instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Water Damage Backlight
threads.message:
I am with this 00165 with backlight issue

First I just found out the filter... replace and still no backlight..Replaced the backlight IC and I do still do not have backlight.


<DIODE>D7701</DIODE>
PIN1 = 8.56
PIN2 = 8.32


Where could I go?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Water Damage Backlight
threads.message: Check XW7720 bridge integrity; lot of info available on the forum, including photos.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Water Damage Backlight
threads.message: I think its okay. I even put a bit of solder on the Test Point itself.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Water Damage Backlight
threads.message:
When you remove <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> is very easy to check the continuity; should do that every time.

Post <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> level.
Try PRAM reset 2-3 times.

"found out the filter"
Filter being what?
